titleStmt.title: A Comedy of the Apocryphal Ladies1662
titleStmt.author: Cavendish, Margaret

editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

availability.licence: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 3.0 Unported License

titleStmt.title: Playes written by the thrice noble, illustrious and excellent princess, the Lady Marchioness of Newcastle.
titleStmt.author: Newcastle, Margaret Cavendish, Duchess of, 1624?-1674.

titleStmt.title: Playes written by the thrice noble, illustrious and excellent princess, the Lady Marchioness of Newcastle.
titleStmt.author: Newcastle, Margaret Cavendish, Duchess of, 1624?-1674.
Newcastle, William Cavendish, 1592-1676.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by A. Warren, for John Martyn, James Allestry, and Tho. Dicas ...,

note.p: Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.head: Prologue
div.l: Noble spectators, this play that you'll see,
Is taken out of Britain's history;
It is not pleasant, nor yields much delight,
But it did serve the poetress to write;
She bids me tell you, she was glad to take
Any dull plot, so she a play could make,
Her vacant idle time for to employ;
For she loves writing more than company;
But if it pleases not your eyes or sight,
She doth not care, since it pleased her to write;
For she endeavours, tries all that she may
To please herself in every honest way;
Wherefore a praise, or yet applause from you,
She expects not, nor challenges as her due.

div.head: A comedy of the apocryphal ladies
Act i.
Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter the unfortunate Duchess, and her woman.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Dear madam, why doth your highness weep?

sp.speaker: Unfortunate Duchess.
sp.p: As fear frights tears from the eyes, so grief doth send them forth.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Why should your highness grieve?

sp.speaker: Unfortunate Duchess.
sp.p: Have I not cause, when I am married to a person which doth not love, but rather hate me?

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Certainly he hath reason to love you, and he were worse than a devil if he should hate you; as first to love you for your virtue and sweet disposition; next for the honour, dignity, and kingdom, he hath got by his marring you: for he hath no right to the dukedom but by your highness, and by your highness he is become an absolute prince, and enjoys a rich kingdom.

sp.speaker: Unfortunate Duchess.
sp.p: But he hath taken the power from me, and strives to dispossess of me of my right.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: He cannot, the kingdom will never suffer him, for your title is so just, as he can make no pretence to dispossess your highness from your princely throne.

sp.speaker: Unfortunate Duchess.
sp.p: But I being his wife, he takes the power of a husband, and by that power, the power of my kingdom, and those that have the power can frame their titles as they please, none dare oppose them.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: The truth is, madam, that might overcomes right.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: The factions and divisions that are in this kingdom will be a means to deliver it into the power of the enemy.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: This Duke is young, wild, deboist and inconstant, wherefore there is but little hopes it should be better governed.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: But the Duchess who is the true owner of it, is discreet, wise, and virtuous, and having more years than he, she might help to rule and order state affairs.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: But neither her discretion, wisdom, nor virtue hath power, for marriage hath enthralled her, for she is become her husband's slave, who ought to be his sovereign, but he laughs and doth despise her, because she is somewhat elder than himself.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Heaven will revenge her wrongs.

div.head: Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter the Duke of inconstancy, and a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Duke inconstancy.
sp.p: Have you been with the lady I sent you to?

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Duke inconstancy.
sp.p: And doth she listen to love's suit?

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: She seems well pleased to hear her beauty praised, but will not hear of amorous embracements as yet.

sp.speaker: Duke inconstancy.
sp.p: But it is a good omen whenas a lady will nimblingly bite at a bait of flattery; but did you see her husband?

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: Duke inconstancy.
sp.p: Well, you must go again, and present her with a letter, and a present from me; for ladies must be plied though they deny, yet most do yield upon a treaty, they cannot long hold out loves fierce assaults.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: Indeed the female sex is tender and weak, although they are delicate and sweet.

sp.speaker: Duke inconstancy.
sp.p: They are false and oft betray themselves.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter the unfortunate Duchess, and her woman; then enters another as running in haste.

sp.speaker: 1 woman.
sp.p: O madam, madam, news is come that the enemy hath got into the heart of the kingdom; wherefore sweet lady fly, for they will possess themselves of this city soon.

sp.speaker: Unfortunate Duchess.
sp.p: I will not fly, for I cannot meet a worse enemy than the Duke himself, should worse than mankind conquer it; but I wish my sister were safe.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: The young Princess I hear is fled to the Duke's brother.

sp.speaker: Unfortunate Duchess.
sp.p: I am glad of it, for he is discreetly temperate, although his brother is not.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter the Duke of inconstancy, and a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: Sir, what will your highness do?

sp.speaker: Duke inconstancy.
sp.p: I will go and oppose the enemy.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: Alas sir you have no forces to oppose them withal, you may go to be destroyed, but not to destroy; wherefore you with your small forces had better fly than fight.

sp.speaker: Duke inconstancy.
sp.p: Whither shall I go?

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: To any prince that will receive you into pay, by which you may maintain yourself, and live with some respect and fame abroad, though you have lost your kingdom; whereas if you stay, you will lose yourself and kingdom too.

sp.speaker: Duke inconstancy.
sp.p: Your counsel I will take.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: But what will your highness do with your Duchess?

sp.speaker: Duke inconstancy.
sp.p: Let her do what she will with herself, I care not now, for since her kingdom is lost, I have no use of her.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: Not as concerning the kingdom sir, but yet she is your highness's wife, and as a husband you ought to regard her.

sp.speaker: Duke inconstancy.
sp.p: She will follow me, for wives stick so close to their husbands as they cannot be shaken off.

div.head: Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter the creating Princess, and her woman.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Pray madam do not marry so much below yourself.

sp.speaker: Create. Princess.
sp.p: Why? what matter whom I marry, since I can create my husband to honour.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: But madam, that honour will do him no good, nor will it take off your disgrace; for none will give your husband, if he be an inferior person, the place and respect that is due to great princes' titles.

sp.speaker: Create. Princess.
sp.p: No, but he shall take place, and my servants shall give him the respect and homage that is due to great titles: for I will make him a prince; and who dare call him any other, but prince?

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: There is none will call him prince, unless your own servants; and none will give him place, that are above the degree of his birth: no, nor he durst not take it of gallant noble men; for if he offers thereat, they will beat him back, and force him to give way, and to be only a prince in his own house, and not abroad, is no better than to be a farmer, nay, a cobbler, or a tailor, or any the like are Kings in their own houses, although they be but thatched, if they have but a servant subject, or subject servant.

sp.speaker: Create. Princess.
sp.p: Well, say what you will, I will make him a prince.

div.head: Scene 7.
div.stage: Enter the Duke of inconstancy, and a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: Sir, doth not your highness hear that your Duchess is gone with your enemies into the country?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Yes, and though I might curse my enemies for dispossessing me of the kingdom I enjoyed, yet I give them thanks for carrying my wife away with them: for now I have more room and liberty to woo and court my mistress.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Sir, the lady beauty's husband's dead.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: So I perceive fortune will be my friend some ways, although she is my foe other ways: for she will crown me with love, although she uncrowns me with power: wherefore return presently back to my mistress, and tell her, that now her husband is dead, and my wife gone into another country, we may marry.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: But your highness cannot marry, as long as the Duchess is alive.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I mean to be like the great Turk, have many wives.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p:
Why, the great Turk hath but one chief wife, the rest are but as concubines: for only the sons of that chief Queen shall be successors to the emperor, unless she hath none; neither can his other children inherit,
unless he be right and lawful emperor: so, that unless your highness had been Duke by inheritance, as an inhereditary Duke, no children, by any other lady, can be inheritors, nor indeed princes, unless they were begotten on the right owner to that title.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Well, since I have no power, but only an empty title, I cannot disadvantage myself, or children: for I have no children as yet, and I have neither power, nor kingdom now: wherefore, if I can enjoy her upon these terms, as the name of wife, it will be well.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: But sir, this part of the world allows but of one wife, wherefore if you should marry this lady, the clergy will excommunicate you, as an adulterer, and the lady, as an adulteress, out of the church.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I had rather be in the lady's bed, than in the church: but I have money, although I have lost my dukedom, and that will help me.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: But not make your marriage lawful.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I care not; for if the marrying, and the name of wife will satisfy the lady, I care not whether it be good or bad, lawful or unlawful, wife or concubine, 'tis all one to me; for I will marry a hundred women, if they will marry me, and let me lie with them.

div.head: Scene 8.
div.stage: Enter the unfortunate Duchess, and her woman.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Your highness bears afflictions more courageously than I thought your highness would have done.

sp.speaker: Unfortunate Duchess.
sp.p: Truly, I find I am more happy since I am amongst my enemies (If they may be termed so) than I was in my own country with an unkind husband: for they allow me a noble and princely pension: and I live free, easily and peaceably, which I did not before.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: I hear your sister is married to the Duke's brother.

sp.speaker: Unf. Duchess.
sp.p: I wish she may be more happy with her husband, than I have been with mine.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: If they have children, and your highness none, they will be heirs to the dukedom.

sp.speaker: Unf. Duchess.
sp.p: They will so, but there is no dukedom now to heir, 'tis made now a province.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: But times may change.

div.head: Scene. 9.
div.stage: Enter the comical Duchess, and her woman.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Now you are an absolute Duchess, you must carry yourself in state, and live magnificently, like as an absolute Princess as you are.

sp.speaker: Comical Duchess.
sp.p: Yes, but it is a great affliction for the Duke and I to be banished, and driven out of our kingdom.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Alas madam, great princes have many times great misfortunes; but you must bear your misfortunes with a princely magnanimity.

sp.speaker: Comical Duchess.
sp.p: But if I have children, alas what shall they do?

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: But those that did never enjoy the possession, cannot repine, nor grieve for the loss.

sp.speaker: Comical Duchess.
sp.p: You say true.

div.head: Scene 10.
div.stage: Enter the creating Princess, and her woman.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Pray madam do not marry so meanly, for you cannot entitle him a prince.

sp.speaker: Creating Princess.
sp.p: Well, well, say what you will, I will make him a prince; for why may not I as well make my husband lawfully a prince, as well as the Duke of inconstancy makes the lady beauty a Duchess, and yet hath another wife?

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Introth it will be just like a poor beggar woman in Engl. being mad she said she was Queen Elizabeth of Engl., and all the boys, girls, and common people would run after her, and call her Queen Elizabeth in sport and jest; the like was a poor mad beggar man in France, which said he was King Henry the 4th. of France; but the only difference will be, that you and the comical Duchess have means and wealth enough to live in principy, and they had none, but were so poor they were forced to beg, so could not act their parts.

sp.speaker: Creating Princess.
sp.p: You are a bold rude wench, therefore get you out of my service.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Truly I would not stay in it if I might, for I should be ashamed.

div.head: Scene 11.
div.stage: Enter the unfortunate Duchess, and her woman.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Madam, doth your highness here of the apocryphal Duchess?

sp.speaker: Unfortunate Duchess.
sp.p: What apocryphal Duchess?

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Why the Duke hath married another lady.

sp.speaker: Unfortunate Duchess.
sp.p: That he cannot, until I die, 'tis true a mistress may take the name of a wife, but cannot possess the right of a wife.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: She will be as a Duchess in a play, she will only act the part of greatness.

sp.speaker: Unfortunate Duchess.
sp.p: Indeed most stage-players are courtesans.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: And most courtesans are good actors.

sp.speaker: Unfortunate Duchess.
sp.p: I make no question but she will now have enough spectators.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: But I hope they will hiss her from off the stage.

div.head: Scene 12.
div.stage: Enter the creating Princess, and her husband.

sp.speaker: Creating Princess.
sp.p: Have I married you who was a mean fellow, and have not I made you a prince, and you to deny to pay my debts?

sp.speaker: Husband.
sp.p: But I thought you would have rather enriched me, than have made me poorer than I was.

sp.speaker: Creating Princess.
sp.p: Have I not enriched you with titles? do not all my servants call you prince? and do not all the tradesmen where we buy all our commodities, when they come to our palace do the same, call you prince, and do you reverence?

sp.speaker: Husband.
sp.p: Yes for hopes of gain.

sp.speaker: Creating Princess.
sp.p: I am sure you will gain little reputation or respect if you carry yourself so sneakingly as you do, whereas you should carry yourself like a prince, bravely.

sp.speaker: Husband.
sp.p: Put when all our money is gone we shall be but poor princes: I had better have keep to my trade than to have been a prince, where if I had I should have been rich, now I shall be a beggar.

sp.speaker: Creating Princess.
sp.p: You are so mean a fellow as you cannot be sensible of the honour and dignity I have bestowed upon you.

div.head: Scene 13.
div.stage: Enter the comical Duchess big with child, she sits under her canopy in a chair of state, her attendants by her wait on her.

sp.speaker: 1 attendant.
sp.p: All the great ladies are so envious at your highness, as there will none of them come near you.

sp.speaker: Comical Duchess.
sp.p: I like the company of burghers wives better, for they are my slaves.

sp.speaker: 2 attendant.
sp.p: Yes madam, but your highness is forced I think to present them with some presents now and then; for the world is so wicked, that they will not give true honour it's due, unless they are bribed.

sp.speaker: 3 attendant.
sp.p: You say true, but men will give ladies their due right.

sp.speaker: 4 attendant.
sp.p: Yes, men are more generous and bountiful to ladies; but yet they must be bribed with hopes of obtaining some favours, otherways, I fear me they would be as reserved, and retired from your highness's court as the great ladies are.

sp.speaker: Comical Duchess.
sp.p: I wonder they should, I being an absolute Princess.

sp.speaker: 2 attendant.
sp.p: Yes, but since your titles, rights and marriage is renounced against, they are not so civil, dutiful, and obedient as they were, not considering as they ought to do, that right cannot be renounced against.

sp.speaker: 3. Attendant.
sp.p: But her highness doth show them their error, and that she shows them it cannot be taken from her; for she keeps the same state she did, and is as merry, gay and Frolic, to let the world see, she understands her own greatness best.

sp.speaker: 1. Attendant.
sp.p: But yet there are but few of any nation, but the inferior sort, that come to her highness' court, unless it be the red ochre knights and ladies, and if it were not for them, this court would be empty.

sp.speaker: Comical Duchess.
sp.p: Indeed I am obliged to them more than any other nation, for they give me all the due respects and homage to my greatness; for which I love that nation very well.

sp.speaker: 2. Attendant.
sp.p: You have reason, but I do observe there is nothing doth keep up a court more than dancing, and several sorts and kinds of merry pastime; for wheresoever there is dancing and sport, company will flock together.

sp.speaker: 3. Attendant.
sp.p: You say true.

sp.speaker: Comical Duchess.
sp.p: I find myself full of pain; I believe I shall fall in labour.

sp.speaker: 4. Attendant.
sp.p: I hope than we shall have a young prince, or Princess soon.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: I saw prince Shadow.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: What prince is he?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Why he is the creating Princess's husband, who made him a prince.

sp.speaker: 3. Gent.
sp.p: I thought no women could give title to their husbands, unless they had been sovereigns.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Oh yes, all women can give their husband's titles, if they please.

sp.speaker: 3. Gent.
sp.p: What title?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Why the title of cuckolds.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Indeed most women do magnify their husbands by those titles.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: But let me tell you, that those women that have inheritary honours, although not sovereigns, may endue their husbands with the same honour: but it is not generally so; but his children begotten on her are endued, and not the husband, yet some husbands are. As for example; a lord, vicount, Earl, marquis, Duke, King, or emperor, if the honour, as title, goeth to the female, for default of a male, in some nations their husbands are endued with their titles, but not commonly known to be so in England; as a wife with her husband, which is only during life, and not inhereditary: but if their titles are only during life, and not inhereditary, it cannot derive to another, that is not an successor's for inhereditary honour go like entailed lands, it goeth only to the next heir; but those that are the dignified, are like those that have jointures, or annuitles for life; so when a husband receives a dignity from a wife, or a wife from a husband, it is but so much honour for life.

sp.speaker: 1. Gentleman.
sp.p: But if they have children, those children inherit the honour.

sp.speaker: 2. Gentleman.
sp.p: Yes, as having a right from that parent that is the dignifier, but if there be none of the line of the dignifier, the honour dies, neither is the root of the honour left to any more than one: for though the branches of honour spread to all the children, yet the root remains but with one: for, say a King have many children, they are all princes, but yet there can be but one that can inherit the crown and royalty: so if a marquis, or Duke have many children, they are all lords and ladies, if they be lawfully, and in true wedlock born, otherwise they are not: neither doth any more but one of the legitimate children inherit the root, as to be marquis or Duke, Duchess or Marchioness: neither do the daughters inherit, if there be sons.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: But cannot a Duke's daughter make her husband a prince?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: No, not except she hath the inhereditary honour: for if a King's daughter should marry a private gentleman, he would remain as only in the title of a gentleman, unless the King did create a title for him, or bestow a title on him.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Why? put case the inhereditary honour lay in the people, and they elect a King, hath that King no power to create, or to give honour?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: No, they may choose officers, but not give titles, unless the people did dispossess them of their hereditary power, and give it to any man, and then the root of honour lies in him.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Nor doth his children receive no titles from their father?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: No, for the title he hath, is none of his, he hath it but during life, unless the people will give a lease, as for two or three lives, yet they nominate those two or three lives: so neither can they dispose of their leases, or alter them, but at the people's pleasure; like as those that are made governors, they cannot dispose of their governments to whom they please, as without the leave of those that placed them in the government, neither do his children receive any titles therefrom; like as a lord mayor, his son is not my lord mayor after him, unless he is made one; nor his children have no place by his office, and an elective prince, is but as a lord mayor, or rather like as a deputy governor, who as I said, may dispose of places or offices, but not give dignities, honours, or titles.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: I thank you for your information, for I was so ignorant, as I knew nothing of heraldry.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Have you seen the imaginary Queen yet?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: What imaginary Queen?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Why a great Queen, that every one goeth to kiss her hand.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: From what parts of the world came she?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: From the North parts.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: And do so many go to kiss her hand?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Yes, throngings of common people.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: They would kiss the dog's tail if it were turned up and presented to them: but do any of the nobles and gentry kiss her hand?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Some few that are newly come out of the country to see sights in the city.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Pish, in this age there are so many of these kind of bedlams, as I am weary to hear of them, as the comical Duchess, the creating Princess, and the created prince, prince Shadow, and now the imaginary Queen.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Why faith it is as good a sight as to see a play.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: A puppet play you mean; but the truth is, it is a disgrace to all noble persons, and great dignities, and true titles, to be thus mocked by imitators, it is a sign that all Europe is embroiled in wars so much as every one doth what they list.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Why they are so far from being checked or discountenanced for it, as there are many true princes, great and noble persons as give the same respect and homage as if they were real princes indeed and in truth.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Then it if it were in my power I would divest those that had the right, and true dignities, and titles, and put them upon those that only acted princely and royal parts, since the actors bear up so nobly, and the spectators do creep and crouch so basely: but indeed both sides are actors, both the spectators and players, only the one side acts noble parts, the other side base parts, the one acts the parts of princes, the other of servants; but I am sorrow to see true honour wounded as it is.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: The truth of it is, true honour lies a bleeding, and none doth offer to power in balsimum.

div.head: Scene 16.
div.stage: Enter the imaginary Queen, her gentleman usher bare headed leads her, her page holds up her train, her woman follows her, and that is all her train, a company of people flock to see her, and kneel to kiss her hand, she bridling in her chin, as thinking that doth advance her state, they kneeling she gives them her hand to kiss, they pray God bless her royalty, she nods them thanks, and then passes away.

sp.speaker: 1 woman.
sp.p: Faith neighbour methinks a Queen is not such a brave and glorious thing as I did imagine it.

sp.speaker: 2 woman.
sp.p: I will tell you truly neighbour, that if I had thought a Queen had been no finer a sight than this Queen is, I would have stayed in my house.

sp.speaker: 3 woman.
sp.p: And so would I, I tell you truly neighbour.

sp.speaker: 4 woman.
sp.p: I perceive Queens are no finer creatures than other women are.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Lord what a ridiculous sight it is to see the imaginary Queen act the part of majesty?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Faith she is so far from majesty, as she cannot act the part, for she appears like a good country housewife.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: She is but a gentlewoman, and that is all.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: We may see the difference of true greatness, and that which is forced, there was the Queen masculine; what a natural majesty did she appear with? for all she had given up her crown and kingdom, yet her royal birth was seen in her princely carriage.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: It was a generous act: but was it in her power to dispossess herself of her natural inheritance?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: It seems so; and it seems by her actions that she had rather see the world abroad, than rule a kingdom at home, for she hath travelled most of all Europe over.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: She appears to be a royal lady.

div.head: Scene 18.
div.stage: Enter two or three of the comical Duchess' women, and two or three burghers wives.

sp.speaker: 1 woman.
sp.p: The comical Duchess is brought to bed or the sweetest Princess that ever was bore.

sp.speaker: 1 wife.
sp.p: Indeed it is the sweetest Princess that ever was born.

sp.speaker: 2 wife.
sp.p: We are glad we hope her highness will sleep well tonight .

sp.speaker: 1 wife.
sp.p: Pray present our most humble and obedient duty to her highness.

sp.speaker: 1 woman.
sp.p: Will you not go in and see her, and kiss the young Princess's hand?

sp.speaker: 1 wife.
sp.p: If we may be so much honoured, we shall be very proud of that grace and honour.

sp.speaker: 2 woman.
sp.p: Come, come, we will prefer you to that grace and favour.

sp.speaker: 1. Wife.
sp.p: Welcome mistress ink-pot, whether are you going so hastily?

sp.speaker: 2. Wife.
sp.p: Truly mistress paper, I am going to her highness the comical Duchess, for I hear she is brought a-bed of a sweet young Princess.

sp.speaker: 1. Wife.
sp.p: Is she so? I am glad her highness' pain is past, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: 2. Wife.
sp.p: So am I, for now we shall have dancing again, as soon as her month is passed.

sp.speaker: 1. Wife.
sp.p: Yes, for she will send for us all, as soon as she is able to dance.

sp.speaker: 2. Wife.
sp.p: Yes that she will, and give us all favours to wear for her sake.

sp.speaker: 1. Wife.
sp.p: But to some she gives her picture too.

sp.speaker: 2. Wife.
sp.p: Yes, but those she gives her picture too, are of a higher degree.

sp.speaker: 1. Wife.
sp.p: By your favour, we are of as high a degree as most that visit her.

sp.speaker: 2. Wife.
sp.p: Yes, of the female sex, but not of the masculine sex; for there are great persons that visit her.

sp.speaker: 1. Wife.
sp.p: Very few, but only of the red ochre nation, or some strangers that are travellers, that visit her, as they pass other ways, else the men that visit her, are of as inferior degree as we, as fiddlers, dancers, players, and the like.

sp.speaker: 2. Wife.
sp.p: By your favour, there are sometimes burghers and gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1. Wife.
sp.p: Yes sometimes, when she sends for to invite them to dance, or entreats them to come and visit her; and than she presents them with her colours.

div.head: Scene. 20.
div.stage: Enter the lady true honour, and madam Inquirer.

sp.speaker: Madam Inquirer.
sp.p: Lord, madam, I was asked today, why your honour doth not visit the comical Duchess, nor the imaginary Queen?

sp.speaker: Lady true honour.
sp.p: Why, should I that am entitled with true honour, and princely dignity, which titles were created from an absolute and divine power, give place to mock honours, and feigned dignities? shall princes in royal courts, give place to princes in plays?

sp.speaker: Madam Inquirer.
sp.p: But every one doth not rightly understand a princely dignity.

sp.speaker: Lady true honour.
sp.p:
I will instruct you in the degrees of princes, and their derivation; but first, let me tell you, the princely arms, or seal, is a crown; for a crown is the general arms, or seal of all princely dignities, and every
degree is known and distinguished by the several fashions of their crowns; for a viscount's crown, which is the first degree of a prince, is not like the Earls crown, which is the second degree; nor an Earls crown is not like a marquess's crown, which is the third degree; that is, there is some difference in the crown; nor a marquess's crown is not like a Duke's crown, which is the fourth degree; nor a Duke's crown is not like a close imperial crown, which is the last and highest degree; that is, there is some difference in the crown of each degree: now there are absolute princes, tributary, and subject princes, but none can be wholly called absolute princes, but those that have the imperial crown, which are absolute Kings and emperors, being the only chosen of God, and by that the only creators of titles; for they only are the fountain, or springs of honour.

sp.speaker: Madam Inquirer.
sp.p: How comes it that subjects are made princes?

sp.speaker: Lady true honour.
sp.p: By adoption: for all subject princes are princes by adoption: that is, they are adopted to their princely dignity, so that by adoption, they are the cousins to royalty, and are called by their sovereigns, Kings cousins, and are adorned with royal robes, endued with royal power, and observed with royal ceremony, and are allowed some customs and imposts out of the revenue of the kingdom, and many privileges which belong to the princely dignities: thus Kings call their subject princes, cousins, as being adopted to their princely royalty, like as all absolute monarchs call each other brother, as in relation to each others royalty: and being all of them gods anointed, and appointed deputies on earth, for government and honour, they are the sacred magistrates of God, the divine fountains of honour: thus true honour is derived from heaven, and ought to be respected, and bowed too, as being divine: but in this age honour is used, or abused, as other divine things are: this is the reason I will not visit the apocryphal ladies: for my honour is derived from the sacred spring of honour, and is not a self-given honour and dignity, which ought to be punished as a presumption and usurpation: but I have so much honour, as not to abase the honour and dignity that my husband, and his forefathers were adopted too: and I by marriage, being one with my husband; for man and wife are but one, and my husband's honour being inhereditary, succeeds to his children; wherefore his wife will never give place to mountebanks.

sp.speaker: Madam Inquirer.
sp.p: Indeed the strange ridiculousness, and folly, and mad presumption is, that the apocryphal ladies take more state, or at least as much as sacred royalty.

sp.speaker: Lady true honour.
sp.p: But if royalty will suffer such heresies, and heretics in the court of honour, they are not to be lamented, if their courts fall to utter ruin; for it is with titles and dignities, as with laws; if there were no laws, there would be no government, and if there were no degrees and dignities, there would be no royalty; so likewise if the laws be corrupt and abused, government will fall to ruin, and if honour be abused and usurped, royalty will fall from its throne; but howsoever, I keep up the right of my place, because it is the cause and interest of all the nobility of my country, so that if I should give place, I should be a traitor to true honour, and dignified persons.

div.head: Scene 21.
div.stage: Enter two women of the comical Duchess'.

sp.speaker: 1. Woman.
sp.p: Well, now the Duke of inconstancy hath forsaken our lady, his comical Duchess, all our state must down.

sp.speaker: 2. Woman.
sp.p: Yes, and we must lose our places, in going before others, as being Duchess's women.

sp.speaker: 1. Woman.
sp.p: The Duchess cried all night.

div.p: 2. She had no more reason to cry, than she had, for the matter of dignity; for, pray consider, her highness may keep the same state, as being Duchess still, as well as she did before; for she possessed the honour no more than she doth now, and so now no less than she did then.

sp.speaker: 1. Woman.
sp.p: That is true, but the Duke did help to countenance her state, so long as he did live with her, as a husband, whereas now she will be hissed off the stage.

sp.speaker: 2. Woman.
sp.p: Faith confidence, and a resolution will bear her up, wherefore let us persuade her not to be daunted, or put out of countenance, and she having the same estate she had, may maintain herself as high as she hath done.

sp.speaker: 1. Woman.
sp.p: You say true, and the flaunting show will dazzle the eyes, and delude the understanding of the spectators.

sp.speaker: 1. Woman.
sp.p: Yes, of the vulgar.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Honour goes a-begging .

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Why there is an ale wife made a countess.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Why the Earl undone hath married mistress Tip-tape.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: But he hath a wife living.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: That is all one, for did not the Duke of inconstancy marry a lady, and made her a Duchess, although he had a Duchess to his wife before, by whom he was a Duke.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: I perceive great noble persons may do what they will: for if a poor mean man should have two wives at one time, they would be surely punished; nay, in some kingdoms they would be hanged.

sp.speaker: 1. Wife.
sp.p: Do you hear that the Duke of inconstancy hath forsaken his comical Duchess?

sp.speaker: 2. Wife.
sp.p: Yes, but that is nothing.

sp.speaker: 1. Wife.
sp.p: Have you been with her highness since?

sp.speaker: 2. Wife.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: 1. Wife.
sp.p: And how looks she upon her misfortunes?

sp.speaker: 2. Wife.
sp.p: Why she appears the same, and keeps greater state than ever she did; yea, even her children are served more royally than ever.

sp.speaker: 1. Wife.
sp.p: Faith she is to be commended, if it will hold out.

sp.speaker: 2. Wife.
sp.p: As long as she hath money, it will hold.

sp.speaker: 1. Wife.
sp.p: O, money doth all things.

div.head: The epilogue.
div.l: Noble spectators,
In Britain land, long, long ago, I say,
There were such persons, as are in my play;
In chronicle you'll find a story plain,
A Britain Queen that happily did reign.
At last did marry one below her state,
Which merited not a crown, or King fate;
For he, when power got, did put away
His royal wife; and married, as they say,
Another lady; she and he did live
Like lawful King and Queen, till God did give
The ronged Queen, her kingdom back again;
For in a battle, she her husband slain.
And of the rest, in storeys you shall read,
Such persons as my play presents indeed.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
